Imagine a world where you can't use your phone outside of your home country, where every time you travel you have to buy a new phone or router, where all the websites you use are only available in one language. This world could have been a reality if we didn't have global technological standards.
The discussion held by Hudson Institute on June 12 focused on the importance of global technological standards and their impact on current geopolitical issues. The experts pointed out how different countries have different standards for technologies like 5G, artificial intelligence, and the Internet of Things. Some countries want to create their own standards to gain a competitive advantage, while others want to adopt global standards to create interoperability and promote innovation.
For example, China is investing heavily in developing its own 5G technology and standards, which would allow it to dominate the market and potentially gain control over critical infrastructure. Meanwhile, the United States is taking a different approach by promoting open and competitive systems that are interoperable with other countries. The European Union is trying to create its own technological independence while also cooperating with other countries on global standards for sustainability and privacy.
The experts also discussed how technology companies are affected by these standards. Companies like Huawei, which is facing scrutiny over its ties to the Chinese government, are trying to gain access to global markets by adhering to global standards. On the other hand, some companies are pushing their own proprietary standards to gain a competitive advantage.

As we step into a new decade of the 21st century, the world is witnessing a massive shift in the global economy and technological landscape. The rapid pace of technological advancements and the growing need for standardization and interoperability are leading to the fierce competition among nations and corporations for shaping the future of the global digital architecture. The outcomes of this silent tussle will likely determine the course of the digital era and the distribution of power and influence in the decades to come.
The emergence of new technologies such as 5G, artificial intelligence, quantum computing, and the Internet of Things (IoT) is driving the demand for new global technological standards that enable seamless communication, secure data transmission, and efficient resource allocation. At the same time, the lack of common standards and the proliferation of proprietary and conflicting ones pose significant challenges and risks for global interoperability, security, and innovation.
This article aims to shed light on the driving factors, trends, and implications of the global technological standards and geopolitics, with a focus on three key points:
The importance of global technological standards is not a new phenomenon. It dates back to the early days of mass media and the battle between two competing video cassette formats: the VHS (Video Home System) and the Betamax. The VHS eventually won the race, not because it was technically superior, but because it enjoyed wider industry support and lower costs.
Fast forward to today, the stakes are much higher, and the competition is much fiercer. The ongoing trade war between the US and China, which involves the race for 5G supremacy, is a defining and highly publicized example of the strategic importance of standards in the digital age. The US has long been the dominant player in setting international standards through organizations such as the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC).
However, China, which is set to become the largest economy in the world, has been ramping up its efforts to challenge the US-led regime and promote its own standards, such as the proposed New IP (Internet Protocol) for next-generation internet infrastructure. China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) has also been instrumental in spreading its digital connectivity standards to other countries, even as the US has been advocating for its own standards, such as the Clean Network program.
Meanwhile, Europe, which has been traditionally a standardization powerhouse, is also seeking to assert its influence by promoting its own digital sovereignty and standards on issues such as data protection, cybersecurity, and AI ethics.
The race for 5G standards is a prime example of how global technological standards have become a new arena for geopolitical competition. At the heart of this race lies the question of which technology will dominate the future wireless communications and enable new applications such as autonomous driving, smart cities, and virtual reality.
The US has been pushing for its own standards through a coalition of allies known as the "Clean Network," which aims to exclude Chinese equipment and technologies from critical networks. The US has also been promoting its own 5G standards through the Third Generation Partnership Project (3GPP), a global consortium of telecoms standards bodies. However, the US has faced challenges in persuading its allies to join its campaign, as many countries have already invested in Chinese technologies and fear retaliation from China.
China, on the other hand, has been promoting its own 5G standards through its state-controlled telecoms giant Huawei, which has invested heavily in research and development and holds a significant share of 5G patents. Huawei's standards, which are based on a different technology known as Time-Division Long-Term Evolution (TD-LTE), have gained support from several countries in Asia, Africa, and Europe, which are either attracted by the lower costs or influenced by China's economic and diplomatic power. However, Huawei's ambitions have also faced backlash from the US and its allies, which claim that Huawei poses a security risk and could allow Chinese spying.

Whenever a cyclone strikes, it becomes a matter of concern for the authorities as well as the masses. The severity of the situation aggravates when the natural disaster hits densely populated regions. In such cases, prompt action is necessary to mitigate the impact of the cyclonic storm.
The convention of naming a cyclone follows the alphabetical order. The first cyclone of the year is assigned a name beginning with the letter 'A' followed by 'B', 'C', and so on. But have you ever wondered why we name a cyclone?
The idea behind giving names is to simplify communication among the meteorologists, disaster management bodies, and the public. In the case of extreme weather conditions, accurate and prompt communication is crucial for effective disaster management.
The simple reason for naming a cyclone is to create a channel for effective communication. In the era of digitalization and social media, a cyclone's name is the quickest way to spread awareness and disseminate information to the masses. A clear and concise naming structure enables people to remember the name and take prompt action in case of a natural disaster.
The beginning of the 19th century witnessed a shift in the way hurricanes were tracked. It was in 1953 when the US Weather Bureau deployed women's names for the hurricanes. The trend caught up, and the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) initiated the practice of naming the cyclonic storms in the year 1955.
The WMO divided the world into nine regions, headed by different countries' meteorological departments. The countries belonging to the specific region are responsible for naming the tropical cyclones. For example, India belongs to the Bay of Bengal and Arabian Sea region and hence is responsible for naming the cyclones formed in these regions.
Since 2000, the WMO has maintained an updated list of cyclonic storm names. The organization allocates a list of names to each region, and the cycle repeats every six years. The WMO also avoids assigning the names of people so that there is no disrespect or confusion.
Naming a cyclone helps promote awareness and prepares people in advance to minimize the loss during the disaster. For instance, in 2013, the 'Phailin' cyclone happened to be the worst cyclonic storm to hit the Indian peninsula in over a decade. The timely evaluation and prompt process of evacuating the people were the prime reasons for a minimal loss of life.
Again in 2020, Cyclone Amphan struck the eastern coast of India, killing over 100 people and leaving millions displaced. Reliable and accurate information dissemination about the disaster gave the people an idea of what to expect and how to prepare.
Hence, the naming of cyclonic storms is a useful tool to spread awareness and ensure that people remain vigilant. The easy, simple, and clear structure of cyclone names makes it easy for the masses to remember and understand the information.
